intro: Learning how to swim can be scary when you don't know what you're doing. Don't worry though — there are things you can do to make learning how to

steps.title: Try .
steps.subtitle: Dives can be a fun way to get into the water and start a stroke.  Start with a basic dive, and move on to more complicated swan dive, , and .
sub-points: At a bare minimum, the water should be 9 or 10 feet (2.7 or 3.0 m) deep; if you're a tall person, make it at least 11 or 12 feet (3.4 or 3.7 m).

steps.title: Know how to get out of a .
steps.subtitle: If you're caught in a river that's flowing too quickly or pushing you under, follow these steps to get out:
sub-points: Don't flail or panic.  As with a rip current, panicking and flailing your limbs can push you deeper into the water.  Try to take even breaths and remain calm.

Aim to swim diagonally toward the shoreline.  Swimming toward the shoreline at a 90-degree angle will force you to fight with the current too much, and might cause you to become exhausted quickly.  Instead, plan to get to the shoreline at a diagonal angle that goes  the current.
Don't try to swim upstream.  You'll spend too much energy for not enough results.   try to swim upstream if there's immediate danger downstream, such as sharp rocks or a waterfall.
If you are being rapidly carried downstream by the current, point your feet in the direction you are being carried. This may prevent you from striking your head on a rock or other obstruction.
